Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An angry client is loudly criticising a cut moments before the salon is due to close.
Situation2: They have been scheduled to chant a portion during the service.
Story: The clock on the salon wall ticked closer to six, and my hands trembled as I tried to calm the angry client in my chair. She glared at her reflection, her voice rising with every complaint about the cut. I could feel the eyes of my coworkers on me, silently urging me to resolve the situation quickly so we could all go home. But tonight wasn’t just any night—I was scheduled to chant a Torah portion at synagogue, something I’d practiced for weeks. The service would start soon, and I knew the congregation was counting on me. My phone buzzed in my pocket, a reminder of the time, and my heart pounded with guilt. I wanted to give my client the attention she deserved, to fix her hair and send her home happy, but I also felt the weight of my commitment to my faith and community. Torn between my professional duty and my religious responsibility, I stood frozen, caught in the impossible space between two worlds that both needed me, right now.
